DataElement.preferredName: Patient Neurofibromatosis Personal Medical History Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria Yes No Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The yes/no indicator related to a patient's record of past events of a disorder characterized by an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance with high rates of spontaneous mutation and multiple neurofibromas or neurilemmomas to allow an individual to participate in a clinical trial.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Patient Neurofibromatosis Personal Medical History Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to a patient's record of past events of a disorder characterized by an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance with high rates of spontaneous mutation and multiple neurofibromas or neurilemmomas to allow an individual to participate in a clinical trial.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A person who requires medical care.

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

Property.preferredName: Neurofibromatosis Personal Medical History Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria
Property.preferredDefinition: A group of disorders characterized by an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance with high rates of spontaneous mutation and multiple neurofibromas or neurilemmomas. NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 1 (generalized neurofibromatosis) accounts for approximately 95% of cases, although multiple additional subtypes (e.g., NEUROFIBROMATOSIS 2, neurofibromatosis 3, etc.) have been described. (From Neurochirurgie 1998 Nov;44(4):267-72):A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.:Elements of a personal medical history which are necessary to allow an individual to participate in a specific clinical trial.

Concepts.definition: An autosomal dominant hereditary neoplastic syndrome. Two distinct clinicopathological entities are recognized: neurofibromatosis type 1 and neurofibromatosis type 2. Neurofibromatosis type 1 is associated with the presence of cafe-au-lait cutaneous lesions, multiple neurofibromas, malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, optic nerve gliomas, and bone lesions. Neurofibromatosis type 2 is associated with the presence of schwannomas, meningiomas, and gliomas.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
Characteristics which are necessary to allow a subject to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol. The concept covers inclusion and exclusion criteria.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: trial-specific criteria that a patient must meet to be enrolled.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Does patient have a known his
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have a known history of NF1 (Neurofibromatosis Type 1) and a history of a tumor of the central nervous system (astrocytoma or optic glioma)?

ReferenceDocuments.name: PBTC_Text1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have neurofibromatosis type 1?

ReferenceDocuments.name: COG CRF Text 1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) based on clinical criteria and/or germline genetic testing?

ReferenceDocuments.name: COG CRF Text 02
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have a known diagnosis of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)?

ReferenceDocuments.name: COG CRF Text 03
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have a known diagnosis of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) or tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC)?
